The Virtual DOM

What is it?

Imagine you're building a house of cards – you stack up playing cards in a specific order to create your card house. Now, let's relate this to web development and React's Virtual DOM. REAL DOM:Think of the "real DOM" like a physical version of your card house. It's the actual structure of your web page that your browser creates based on the HTML you write. Every time you want to change something, like adding or removing a card, you need to rebuild the whole card house. This can be slow and tedious if you have a big card house.

Virtual DOM: Now, imagine you have a blueprint of your card house, where you can plan changes without touching the actual cards. This "blueprint" is the "Virtual DOM." Instead of directly modifying the real card house, you make changes to this blueprint.

Rendering

What it's all about

In React, you define your user interface using components. Each component has a render method that returns a virtual representation of the UI for that component. When a change occurs in your application, such as new data or a user interaction, React creates a new virtual DOM representation of the updated UI. This new virtual representation is then compared with the previous one. we call this Reconciliation.
